intro: Phyllostegia ambigua var. longipes, commonly known as the long-stemmed false mallow, is a perennial herb native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant features opposite, ovate leaves with serrated margins and produces showy, pink to purple flowers in the summer. Its stems are slender and often branched, with a hairy texture. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and stream banks.
